biases.name: REPRESSION
biases.description: Xaya's authoritarianism grows as civilians become an 'assisting police force'.
biases.headline: Xaya's new security program is set to surveil the entirety of the public space.
biases.text:
The Xayan government has just published a report on its new SafeNet program, detailing its components and results. SafeNet was tested in eight rural areas with the installation of more than 500 security cameras and 7000 microphones. Through special telephone lines installed in their homes, local residents can hear live security footage, and call the police by pressing '0' if they detect suspicious activity.
    This system creates a feeling of 'permanent surveillance' between the citizens, as even the most insignificant actions can lead to being reported. This has raised concerns on the potential consequences of minor conflicts between neighbours, as they could lead to arbitrary denounces.
    Besides that, the non-profit organisation International Action for Human Rights has stated that 'SafeNet is an outrageous violation of basic human rights' and a confirmation of Xaya's 'growing authoritarianism'.
    In a press conference, state representatives declared that they are already working on implementing SafeNet in urban areas, including the capital.

biases.name: SAFETY
biases.description: Innovative program boosts security thanks to civilian collaboration.
biases.headline: Crime drops by 10% in Xaya as government deploys SafeNet plan.
biases.text:
The Xayan government has just published a report on its new SafeNet program, detailing its components and results. SafeNet was tested in eight rural areas and in only two months has surpassed all expectations: crime, which was already at its lowest, has dropped by 10%.
    In a press conference, state representatives argued that the citizens' collaboration has been key for success. SafeNet eases the detection of even the slightest suspicious behaviours, thus preventing crime from happening. The plan has proven to be specially effective against robbery, vandalism and disorderly conduct, the most common types of crime in Xaya.
    The government has asserted that they are already working on implementing SafeNet in urban areas, including the capital. Thomas Doe, Minister of Security and Welfare, declared that Xaya is 'on the right way' to achieving its goal of the eradication of crime and creating a 'country where everyone feels safe'. 'In 10 years, commiting a crime will not be possible in Xaya', assured Doe.
